00031 /// @file xed-decode.h 
00032 /// @author Mark Charney   <mark.charney@intel.com> 
00033 
00034 
00035 #ifndef _XED_DECODE_H_
00036 # define _XED_DECODE_H_
00037 
00038 
00039 #include "xed-decoded-inst.h"
00040 #include "xed-error-enum.h"
00041 ////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00042 // DEFINES
00043 ////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00044 
00045 ////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////

00055 /// This is the main interface to the decoder.
00056 ///  @param xedd the decoded instruction of type #xed_decoded_inst_t . Mode/state sent in via xedd; See the #xed_state_t
00057 ///  @param itext the pointer to the array of instruction text bytes
00058 ///  @param bytes  the length of the itext input array. 1 to 15 bytes, anything more is ignored.
00059 ///  @return #xed_error_enum_t indiciating success (#XED_ERROR_NONE) or failure. Note failure can be due to not
00060 ///  enough bytes in the input array.
00061 ///
00062 /// The maximum instruction is 15B and XED will tell you how long the
00063 /// actual instruction is via an API function call
00064 /// xed_decoded_inst_get_length().  However, it is not always safe or
00065 /// advisable for XED to read 15 bytes if the decode location is at the
00066 /// boundary of some sort of protection limit. For example, if one is
00067 /// decoding near the end of a page and the XED user does not want to cause
00068 /// extra page faults, one might send in the number of bytes that would
00069 /// stop at the page boundary. In this case, XED might not be able to
00070 /// decode the instruction and would return an error. The XED user would
00071 /// then have to decide if it was safe to touch the next page and try again
00072 /// to decode with more bytes.  Also sometimes the user process does not
00073 /// have read access to the next page and this allows the user to prevent
00074 /// XED from causing process termination by limiting the memory range that
00075 /// XED will access.  
00076 ///
00077 /// @ingroup DEC
00078 XED_DLL_EXPORT xed_error_enum_t
00079 xed_decode(xed_decoded_inst_t* xedd, 
00080            const xed_uint8_t* itext, 
00081            const unsigned int bytes);
00082 
00083 
00084 ////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00085 // GLOBALS
00086 ////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00087 
00088 
00089 #endif
